subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Quickscript in other countries
msgSnippet: Thx for the links Jean-Francois. B. J. Jean-François Colson  wrote: Here are a few interesting links about Shavian in Esperanto and QS
messageBody:
Thx for the links Jean-Francois.
 
B. J.

Jean-François Colson <jfcolson@...> wrote:
Here are a few interesting links about Shavian in Esperanto and QS in Dutch.
 
http://en.wikipedia .org/wiki/ Quickscript
http://nl.wikipedia .org/wiki/ Quickscript
http://en.wikipedia .org/wiki/ Shavian
http://eo.wikipedia .org/wiki/ %C5%9Cava_ alfabeto
http://esperanto. us/sxava_ alfabeto/
 
JF
 
----- Original Message -----
From: Susan&BJ
To: Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com
Sent: Wednesday, August 23, 2006 1:42 PM
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Quickscript in other countries

Most other languages outside English are (almost) phonetic, so they do not have a great need for a writing system like Shavian or Quikskript. However they do have their own shorthand systems. By the way I would be interested in seeing the Dutch versions of both.
 
B. J.

tim_rice09 <tim_rice09@yahoo. com> wrote:
The problem with adapting Quickscript to other languages is that
English is well, wierd. Only 2 of the cardinal vowels are present and
are quite off-glided. Also, Quickscript lacks letters for say the
Spanish Ñ and the Russian soft sign. Not to mention the rolled R which
is needed for languages with both types of the sound. Are there any
Armenians here?

--- In Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com, "ramsesoudt" <tommie222@.. .>
wrote:
>
> I'm very curious about how big Quikscript is in other countries. For
> example: are there any foreigners in this group? I'm from the
> Netherlands, but because I speak English pretty well I came across
> Quikscript and learned it myself after that I learned to use
Shavian.
> After that, I transliterated Shavian for the use in Dutch and some
time
> later I found a transliteration of Quikscript for use in Dutch.
>
> But I'm curious how big it is in other countries and if there are
more
> transliterations. ..
>
